Text: We are not slaves to the state. We own our bodies. Personal Liberty lost ground today, but despots only win when we let them.

Roe was never just about abortion. “Killing babies” was merely an emotional wedge to force reversal of progress on a fundamental question. How much authority does government have to regulate and criminalize the most intimate decisions in our lives?

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations said in April that Russia’s war on Ukraine was mostly responsible for the 17.1% rise in the price of wheat, barley, corn and other grains.”
“Russia’s war on Ukraine has caused a ripple effect across the globe: It has disrupted supply chains and contributed to the surge in rising fuel prices and scarcity of grains and fertilizer…
Our food security shouldn’t be threatened by the whims of a fascist thug on the other side of the globe.

The current crisis must be resolved, but going forward we must look to diversify and build resiliencency in our domestic food production. Government must work with farmers and processors to build local capacity.

The blood of tens of thousands of combatants and innocent civilians are already dripping from the hands of Putin. As the war drags on the death toll will rise as global food shortages and costs mount. We must stay vigilant at home and abroad.

Screaming and demeaning doesn’t change peoples minds and how we do things. Once again—it’s the market and the free exchange of goods, services, and ideas that will push us towards change.

A system dependent on the importation of materials to grow food might be efficient now, but it lacks resiliency and longterm sustainability. This lack of depth will lead to food scarcity, upheaval, and loss of life in the coming years just as it did in in the MENA during 2012.

These rights, too, cannot be justified under the Court’s approach in Justice Alito’s draft opinion.”

…the right of parents to control the upbringing of their children, the right of competent adults to refuse medical care, and the right of consenting adults to engage in same-sex sexual activity under the liberty of the due process clause.

But this right cannot be found in the text, the original meaning, or tradition. Likewise, the Court has protected the right to procreate, the right to custody of one’s children, the right to keep the family together,…

It wasn’t until 1967, in Loving v. Virginia, and 2015, in Obergefell v. Hodges, that the Court protected a constitutional right to marry striking down laws prohibiting interracial marriage in the former case and laws forbidding same-sex marriage in the latter.

I expect that after Roe is overruled some states will quickly pass laws prohibiting types of contraceptives that act after conception, like the IUD and the morning-after-pill. Under Justice Alito’s reasoning, those laws too would be constitutional. Or consider the right to marry.
It, too, is not a right in the text of the Constitution or contemplated when the document was ratified or that was historically protected.
“…it was not until 1965, in Griswold v. Connecticut, that the Court held that the Constitution protects a right to purchase and use contraceptives…

The more power government is granted the more levers zealots have to pull to control and regulate our lives. This SCOTUS opinion does just that and the reverberations will shatter more than most even know.

Unless you want the American Taliban looking over your shoulder, regulating  your bedroom, controlling your doctor’s office, watching your uterus, and erasing your parental rights you should be appalled and scared.
I don’t care if you call yourself pro-choice, pro-life, anti-choice, pro-birth, or any other splattering of loaded phrases.

What he fails to mention is that we are far removed from the America of the 1700s when women were essentially legal property of their husbands with zero rights. Reversion to such a tyrannical state is not an option.

Justice Alito is right on one point. This right was not explicitly included in the text of the Constitution, was not protected by the original meaning of the Constitution, and was not traditionally safeguarded as a constitutional right.
We have the autonomy to modify our bodies. We certainly have the inalienable right to decide if and when we reproduce. Nothing is more natural and foundational than that.

Erasing a natural right codified by nearly five decades of judicial precedent says we don’t. 

Justice Alito is wrong. We own our bodies. We have the sovereignty to determine what we put in our bodies. We have the authority to dictate what we do to our bodies.
It’s in 3rd amendment, the 4th, the 14th, and in boldface italics in the preamble. We either own our bodies or we don’t. We either have the power to determine what we do with our bodies or we don’t.

He claims that almost five decades a group of five justices nominated by Republicans presidents along with two nominated by Democrats made up a right. Make no mistake—the right to privacy—of self determination—of personal Liberty is embedded throughout the US Constitution.

This SCOTUS decision is about much more than just abortion now. Justice Alito’s draft legal opinion is a frontal attack on personal Liberty.
